conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for the clear question and for continuing to communicate your commitment to School_C.

On your specific proposal: if we reach the end of Round 13 and we still have not received an [APPLY] from Student_B, Student_A, or Student_D, we *will* conduct the status review we mentioned—but we cannot commit today to automatically extending an offer to you at that point.

The reason is that our decision at Round 13 depends not only on whether we have received an [APPLY] from those higher-priority students, but also on whether they appear likely to approach us shortly thereafter (e.g., if they remain unmatched and their higher-choice options are closing). In other words, “no [APPLY] yet” is necessary for us to reconsider you, but it is not always sufficient to finalize an offer at Round 13.

What we *can* commit to is this:
- End of Round 13: we will make a concrete go/no-go determination on whether it is still reasonable to hold the seat for higher-priority candidates.
- If, at that time, we assess that a higher-priority [APPLY] is unlikely to materialize in time, we will be prepared to reconsider you immediately for the open seat.
- End of Round 15 remains our latest planned milestone to stop holding the seat absent a higher-priority [APPLY].

If you’d like to maximize the chance of a quick decision at the Round 13 review, please message us again in Round 13 (and you are welcome to submit an [APPLY] then), so we can respond based on the live state of the market.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_E is on our priority list but below Student_B/Student_A/Student_D. Our quota is 1 and we are currently unmatched, so accepting E now risks blocking a higher-priority match later. Student_E is asking for a commitment to offer at end of Round 13 if no higher-priority APPLY arrives. Given uncertainty about late applications (especially Student_B, who ranks School_C #2), it is not optimal to pre-commit at Round 13; we should keep flexibility through the stated Round 15 milestone. We can, however, offer a conditional plan: we will make a decision at Round 13 status check based on whether higher-priority students are still plausibly available/unmatched, without guaranteeing. Continue TALK and maintain E’s engagement so we can fill later if needed.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you again for your transparency. I’m writing in Round 12 to reiterate that School_C remains my clear first choice, and if admitted at any point I will accept immediately and commit to enrolling.

To help me plan and to be responsive at your end-of-Round-13 review, could you share what specific “live market” signals you will use to judge whether a higher-priority [APPLY] from Student_B/Student_A/Student_D is still likely (e.g., whether they are still unmatched, whether their top options are already filled, etc.)?

Also, for the Round 13 check: would you prefer that I submit a fresh [APPLY] in Round 13 to enable an immediate decision if you determine it’s no longer reasonable to hold the seat, or should I simply [TALK] and then apply if you indicate you’re ready?

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my true first choice. School_C has repeatedly said it is holding the seat for higher-priority students (B/A/D) and will do a status check at the end of Round 13. In Round 12, the best move is to stay salient without forcing an early decision they’ve said they can’t commit to. I will use [TALK] to (1) reaffirm commitment, (2) ask what concrete market signals they will use at the Round 13 review, and (3) ask whether submitting an [APPLY] in Round 13 is the preferred way to trigger immediate reconsideration if they decide to stop holding the seat.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you—those are fair questions, and I appreciate how proactively you’re planning.

For our end-of-Round-13 review, the main “live market” signals we will look at are:

1) **Whether higher-priority students are still unmatched.** In particular, Student_B is the key case for us because School_C is relatively high on their preference list.
2) **Whether those students’ higher-choice schools appear to be filled/committed.** For Student_B, the most important indicator is whether **School_E** (their #1) has effectively committed to someone else, making it more likely they move to their next option(s).
3) **Whether those students have begun applying further down their lists.** If we observe (or can reasonably infer from the market state) that a higher-priority student is starting to apply to lower-ranked schools, that increases the chance they may reach School_C soon.
4) **Time/round pressure and remaining outside options.** If it looks like a higher-priority student still has plausible paths to match elsewhere, we are more likely to keep holding; if those paths are closing, we reassess.

On your second question: **yes—our preference is that you submit a fresh [APPLY] in Round 13.** That way, if our Round-13 review concludes it is no longer reasonable to hold the seat for higher-priority candidates, we can respond immediately with a definitive decision rather than adding an extra round.

If you’d like, you can also include a one-line note in that Round 13 [APPLY] reaffirming that you will accept immediately if offered; that is helpful for us administratively.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on our true priority list (ahead of Student_C but behind Student_B/Student_A/Student_D). We still have quota 1 and are currently unmatched. Based on students’ preferences, Student_B ranks School_C 2nd (after School_E), Student_C ranks School_C 2nd (after School_D), while Student_A and Student_D rank School_C last. Thus, the main realistic higher-priority threat is Student_B (and to a lesser extent Student_A/Student_D are unlikely). We have repeatedly rejected Student_E to preserve the seat for higher-priority candidates, and we’ve communicated a Round 13 status check and Round 15 latest milestone. In this round Student_E sent [TALK], asking what signals we’ll use and whether to submit [APPLY] in Round 13. Best response: be transparent about the signals (whether higher-priority students are unmatched, whether their top choices are filled, and whether they’ve started applying down their list), and advise Student_E to submit an [APPLY] in Round 13 so we can accept immediately if we decide to stop holding. Keep door open without committing prematurely.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for submitting your Round 13 application and for clearly reaffirming that School_C is your first choice and that you would enroll immediately if admitted.

After completing our end-of-Round-13 review, we are **not able to offer you admission at this time**. While we still have not received an [APPLY] from Student_B/Student_A/Student_D, based on the current market information we believe there remains a meaningful likelihood that a higher-priority candidate—especially **Student_B**—may still apply to School_C in the next rounds if their higher-choice option does not work out. For that reason, we are continuing to hold the seat for now.

As we previously shared, **end of Round 15** remains our latest planned milestone to stop holding the seat absent a higher-priority [APPLY]. If we are still unfilled then and have not received an [APPLY] from a higher-priority student, we will be prepared to reassess promptly, and you are welcome to submit another [APPLY] at that time.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority order is B > A > D > E > C, quota 1. Student_E is acceptable (4th), but I prefer to keep the seat open if there is a reasonable chance of receiving an application from higher-priority students B/A/D. Given full information: Student_B ranks School_C #2 (after School_E), so if Student_B fails at School_E, they are very likely to apply to School_C; this is a strong reason to continue holding. Student_A ranks School_C last, so unlikely. Student_D ranks School_C last, also unlikely. Therefore the key risk is Student_B. By Round 13, we still have not received B's apply, but it's still plausible they are pursuing School_E and could come to us later. Accepting E now would block a potential match with B, our top choice, which would be a significant loss. We previously set Round 15 as latest milestone; at Round 13 we committed only to review, not to automatic offer. Decision: reject Student_E now to preserve the seat for possible Student_B, while maintaining transparency and inviting E to re-apply at Round 15 if still open and no higher-priority apply arrives.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you again for your continued transparency. I’m writing in Round 14 to check in briefly.

1) Since your end-of-Round-13 review, have you received any new [APPLY] to School_C from Student_B, Student_A, or Student_D?
2) If not, is there any specific “live market” change you would treat as a trigger to stop holding the seat *before* the end of Round 15 (for example, if School_E becomes filled/committed, or if Student_B matches elsewhere), or should I plan on the Round 15 milestone as the next real decision point?

School_C remains my clear first choice, and if the seat is still open at the end of Round 15 and you have not received a higher-priority [APPLY], I will submit an immediate Round 15 [APPLY] and will accept and commit to enroll if offered.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference, so I should stay engaged and maximize the chance of being reconsidered at the end-of-Round-15 milestone. Since School_C indicated they are still holding for higher-priority candidates and have already rejected my Round-13 APPLY, a TALK in Round 14 is best to (1) confirm whether any higher-priority APPLY has arrived since the Round-13 review, (2) ask what specific market change would trigger an earlier offer before Round 15, and (3) signal that I will submit an immediate Round-15 APPLY if still open—without burning another APPLY this round that is likely to be rejected.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for the check-in.

1) **No**—since our end-of-Round-13 review, we have **not** received any new [APPLY] to School_C from **Student_B, Student_A, or Student_D**.

2) At this point, you should plan on **end of Round 15** as the next real decision milestone. That said, there *are* a few “live market” changes that would cause us to stop holding the seat **before** Round 15, including:
- If we become confident that **Student_B has matched elsewhere** (or otherwise is no longer in a position to apply to us).
- If we receive clear market evidence that **Student_B is moving past School_C** (e.g., applying further down their list in a way that implies they won’t reach us).
- If a **higher-priority student applies to School_C** directly (in which case we would have to act on that application).

Absent one of those clearer signals, Round 15 remains our planned point to make a final call.

If our seat is still open at Round 15 and we still have not received a higher-priority [APPLY], we encourage you to do exactly what you outlined: submit a **Round 15 [APPLY]** so we can respond immediately based on the then-current state.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

Provide transparent answers: no new higher-priority applications received; Round 15 remains the main decision point, but we would stop holding earlier if we learn a higher-priority candidate matched elsewhere or clearly will not apply. Encourage Student_E to submit [APPLY] in Round 15 for immediate decision if still open.
